Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 743eb1c0cb44c955078daa2912767cd6d6bb6432

I've read the above, and it doesn't sound like this behavior is specific to redfish.  Is that right?  If we need to be deleting the gateway at the same time as the ip, is that logic that networkd should be doing?

The other thing I'm not understanding in this patch is I see no matching or handling for if there are multiple IP addresses.  Imagine the case where we have

IPAddresses: ["1.1.1.2", "1.1.1.3"]
Gateway: "1.1.1.1"

And I sent:

PATCH IPAddresses: [{}, nullptr]

This code as written would still clear the gateway, even though the gateway is still valid in the ip address that remains.

I could also imagine a case where someone deletes an ip address before creating another, but expects the gateway to persist.  In CRUD we would want to keep the Gateway in place in that case, right?

What I'm not quite understanding is the part where:

> Without explicit removal the network is left in a condition
that may prevent IP traffic from being able to be sent from the
BMC. 

You're deleting the BMC IP address, of course the network can't send IP traffic without an IP address.  I must be missing something here in what's expected or the setup?

Any visibility you can give would be good.

Ed,

Here's some background.

Reference point 1:
At present, if you send:
PATCH <url>/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth1
{
    "IPv4StaticAddresses": [
        {
            "Address": "192.168.70.3",
            "SubnetMask": "255.255.255.0",
            "Gateway": "192.168.70.1"
        },
        {
            "Address": "192.168.60.55",
            "SubnetMask": "255.255.254.0",
            "Gateway": "192.168.60.1"
        }
    ]
}

BMCWeb iterates over the collection of static addresses, setting an Address/netmask on each pass.
The D-Bus interface allows any number of IPv4 address/netmask combinations.
The D-Bus interface only has a single default gateway.
You will get two static addresses, two different subnet masks, and only a single gateway entry.
The default gateway is assigned to whichever entry in the collection was last processed.

The ethernet.hpp code will set a single "DefaultGateway" property, never more.
Phosphor-network will store one gateway, never more.

Doing the PATCH above will not get the results expected.

In short, don't do the PATCH above with the current
BMCWeb/D-Bus/phosphor-network implementation. Best practice is to assign one,
and only one, static IPv4 address.

Reference point 2:
Get rid of this state.
Let's perform a DELETE operation with the most recent BMCWeb code.
PATCH <url>/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth1
{
    "IPv4StaticAddresses": [
        null,
        null
    ]
}


The IPv4 addresses are removed from the D-Bus list.
The gateway is still assigned, because the independent DefaultGateway D-Bus entry still has a value.
There is chaff in the network.conf file that has not been removed, and cannot be removed.

Reference point 3:
Turn on DHCPv4.

Now we have a problem.
DHCPv4 is going to give an address, netmask, a gateway, and other features.
The gateway assigned by the prior static change is still present.
No one ever deleted it.
What happens to the IPv4 traffic that needs to be sent?
Does it go via the default gateway from the static IPv4?
Does it go via the DHCPv4 gateway?
I believe this is going to be random.
What happens if the cable is moved to another subnet, that perhaps doesn't have 192.xxxx addresses, yet the gateway selected is the 192.xxxx gateway?

There's no guarantee that IPv4 traffic on the interface will function as expected.

Reference point 4:
Restore the BMC network to a 'time zero' state.
Remove the network.conf file, and reboot.

Assign a static address to the BMC as before.
PATCH <url>/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth1
{
     "IPv4StaticAddresses": [
     {
             "Address": "192.168.70.3",
             "SubnetMask": "255.255.255.0",
             "Gateway": "192.168.70.1"
     }
     ]
}

The network.conf file shows the results:[Network]
Gateway=192.168.70.1
Address=192.168.70.3/24
DHCP=ipv6

Now, instead of deleting the address directly, turn on DHCPv4.
PATCH <url>/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc/EthernetInterfaces/eth1
Content-Type: application/json
{
    "DHCPv4": {
        "DHCPEnabled": true
    }
}

The network.conf file is in an unexpected state.
[Network]
Address=192.168.70.3/24
DHCP=true

phosphor-network has done us one favor, and that's to remove the Gateway entry.
It has also done us a disservice by assigning the last known static address to the NIC.
So now the NIC has two active IPv4 addresses.
It's now necessary to issue another PATCH with a *null* element to get rid of the static address.
Alternately phoshpor-network needs to have logic to stop performing this action.

Conclusion:
BMCWeb assigned the gateway as part of the IPv4 address assignment.
BMCWeb needs to be responsible for removing it.

> 
> Now we have a problem.
> DHCPv4 is going to give an address, netmask, a gateway, and other features.
> The gateway assigned by the prior static change is still present.
> No one ever deleted it.

This seems like the core of the problem, and IMO is something phosphor-networkd should just solve.  If you're enabling DHCP, clearly you don't want a static gateway (you want the DHCP gateway), so it should be cleaning that up.

> What happens to the IPv4 traffic that needs to be sent?
> Does it go via the default gateway from the static IPv4?
> Does it go via the DHCPv4 gateway?
> I believe this is going to be random.

Yep.  Makes sense.

> Alternately phoshpor-network needs to have logic to stop performing this action.

Yes, this, although I'm not sure this is something phosphor-networkd can stop, given its APIs are adding one IP address at a time.  I guess it could reject the second one if there's already a gateway set?

> 
> Conclusion:
> BMCWeb assigned the gateway as part of the IPv4 address assignment.
> BMCWeb needs to be responsible for removing it.

Gotcha.  I can see how you came to this conclusion, and the above text makes way more sense than the commit message.

Lets:
1. Have bmcweb reject any request that sets more than one unique gateway, with a "PropertyValueConflict" message back to the user, so this problem on new deployments just straight up isn't possible to hit.
2. Make sure that the code on delete of a SINGLE ip address no longer removes the gateway.  In your example above this would be 

"IPv4StaticAddresses": [{}, null]

Which as the code is written, would delete the gateway, even though it's still valid.

Seem reasonable?

I appreciate you writing up the above.  It makes the issue much more clear, especially with reproduction steps.  If you wanted to get the above filed as a bmcweb bug, that might help others that hit this same thing, and let us track this to conclusion, but I realize that's extra work, so up to you.

I understand that the gateway assigned by the prior static change is still present even after deleting existing static ip address.
I think this issue should be handled in backend networkd d-bus application
Done

please test PATCH to override existing IP address with different subnet gateway
check if it works
Acknowledged

Inspecting the networkd config file isn't really a test.  If there's not an easy way to test this functionally, call that out in your commit message, but it seems like it would be relatively easy to assign a static IP (that could be the same as the DHCP id if you're concerned about your network) then assign a DHCP ip and make sure both keep the bmc on the network?
Done
I'm not familiar enough with networking to judge the merits of this change, but just have one comment on the coding
FYI
Can we use the `IpVersion` enum instead of a bool?
This kind of brings up an interesting question: Why does this change only apply to ip4v?  Wouldn't the same thing happen when deleting ipv6?
There's a whole other set of changes for IPv6GatewayStaticAddress that I assume is taking precedence over this feature.
I'm confused.  If there's another set of changes that obsoletes this one, why is this in review?

IPv4 gateway is associated with static IPv4 addresses while configuring ipv4 addresses as per redfish schema, While IPv6 just requires IP address and prefix while configuring IPv6 address and redfish support IPv6GatewayStaticAddress property for ipv6 gateways.
since configure IP address redfish command takes gateway input while configuring IP address, it should be cleaned as part of delete as well.
Thanks for the feedback Ravi.
Done
this reset/remove IPv4 default gateway should be done after successfully deleting IP address, please move code into callback of delete ip address below.

please use this existing method to update gateway 
updateIPv4DefaultGateway(ifaceId, gateway, asyncResp);

Why does it need to be done after?

Chaining DBus operations makes code a lot more complicated, and gets dangerously close to bmcweb actually doing business logic (which ideally it shouldn't ever do).  If we can avoid it, we should, but I'm open to it if there's a good reason that we can articulate (ideally in a comment).
Done
Done
I think gateway needs to updated while delete and create new IPv4 address as well

I don't think it does.
I have a new scheme that I think addresses this.
This looks unrelated to this patch?  This is probably something that phosphor-networkd should be doing, not bmcweb.
Acknowledged
I have reworked the latest submission to eliminate this altogether.
Done
Enums should be passed by value.
Acknowledged
pass integer values by value, not by const ref please.
Acknowledged

Rather than pass numStaticAddrs through all the layers, is this something we could just do it earlier?  I left a comment where I suspect it could go.

As written, we're chaining this after we do all the deletes, but do we really need to do that?  At the beginning of the patch we know whether it needs to be cleared based on the final state?  That would remove the need to pass a lot of the parameters into the two delete functions and I suspect would greatly simplify this patch.
I have come up with a new schema that removes passing the count.
This comment is now on the wrong line.
Done

Right here we know if we need to clear the DHCP setting, right?  If staticIPv4Count == 0 here, we could just do the DHCP update here on this line, instead of passing the count through to all the delete functions?

I don't think so.
The function is getEthernetIntfData. This is a getter function, not a setter function. Calling this function should not perform a modification action.

It no longer matters with my new submission.

nit, please do on a different line.  predecrement vs postdecrement is not the most obvious thing to review (although this code does look correct), and is a lot clearer if it's done on a separate line before or after the operation.
Acknowledged
Here's a modification that I think handles the issue better.
unrelated?
Unintended.

The args on this look incorrect.  These two args get put into the string:

```
The property '<Arg1>' could not be written because its value would conflict
with the value of the '<Arg2>' property.
```

but you've put a full string in Arg2, so the the produced message isn't going to make sense.


I'd expect something like:

The property 'IPv4StaticAddresses/1/Gateway' could not be written because its value would conflict with the value of the 'IPv4StaticAddresses/0/Gateway'


the pathString variable has the IPv4StaticAddresses/1 part already for you.  I suspect you need to track the last path in gatewayValueAssigned, and change it to a string.

The messages will now emit in one of these forms:
 
"The property ’IPv4StaticAddresses/1/Gateway: 192.168.60.1’ could not be written because its value would conflict with the value of the ’NIC: eth1 Gateway: 192.168.70.1’ property."
or
"The property ’IPv4StaticAddresses/2/Gateway: 192.168.70.1’ could not be written because its value would conflict with the value of the ’IPv4StaticAddresses/1/192.168.60.1’ property."
Updated per your latest.

Thanks for all of your rapid reviews.
I do appreciate it very much.

I suspect you want something like

std::format("IPv4StaticAddresses/{}/Gateway", entryIdx);

as written, this is going to produce a string like

"NIC: eth0 Gateway: 1.1.1.1"

But then you push it into propertyValueConflict as if it's a json path.

I hadn't made the correlation between what is present on the NIC and entryIdx == 1.
In my mind there was no entryIdx yet, and by extension no viable path to report.
However, this clause is intended to cover a leading {}.
why are we appending "/" here?  I suspect you can just do = pathString?
I was punch drunk?

I removed this because the very first action coming into handleIPv4Patch is to collect the Gateway from ethData.gateway.
Your example is:
Leave the first active entry alone '{}', so that means there's an active gateway.
If there isn't an IpV4Data then '{}' is asking to preserve an address that doesn't exist. Return an error.
Since the first entry returned an error, the second entry in your patch won't get processed.
Last minior thing, then from my perspective this is good to go.
This should pass CI now.

This is still not a valid json pointer.  I think you want just


pathString + "/Gateway"

Similar story with the second parameter.
and also clang-tidy is flagging this.

Removed the offending ':'
Switched to using arg1 and arg2 because clang-tidy griped about wasteful temporary strings during the message composition.
It's not just the colon, you shouldn't be adding the value at all.  I made the fix.
Please make sure the change I made makes sense to you.

LGTM.
IMO it's a shame the offending value can't be displayed.
Do I +1 your change? :)
Looks good.
You can, or just tell me that you think it's ok like you did.  I'm not a robot 😊

DMTF is the right place to voice that opinion if you'd like to see it changed.  There's nothing bmcweb can do about that in this commit, but I'm sure if you raised an issue, DMTF would probably just add a new message for posting the property value conflict with the values associated as 4 args instead of the two we have today.  FWIW, PropertyValueConflict itself was added based on the same feedback.
